resources.string:
Help us identify and locate invasive plant and animal species in your area using your Android phone.

Conservation efforts lack up-to-date information on the locations of weeds and pests and you can help by "tagging" locations of invasives using this application.

The National Park Service and local conservation members will use these location data to focus their removal efforts.
Please visit our website for more information:
We are the Center for Embedded Networked Sensing (CENS) at the University of California, Los Angeles.\n
Failed to download list of parks.\n\nMake sure you have network coverage before trying again.
Please wait while downloading invasives info and pictures.
Attempting to download new invasives list...

What\'s Invasive! for Android is designed to automatically upload user data to our What\'s Invasive servers. Would you like to set automatic upload on now? (Note: You can change this value later in Settings)
Take photo by pressing camera button or center directional pad.

Jameel Al-Aziz
Christy Brigham

\nTo edit or delete your previous observations, please visit us at our webpage:
The \"Map a Weed!\" or \"Map a Pest!\" buttons are the main functions.

When connected, your phone will automatically download a list of participating parks. If GPS is enabled, your phone will also automatically select the closest park.\n\nIf you wish to manually select a park from the list, go to:
Automatic List of Weeds and/or Pests

Your phone will also download the current list of top invasives for you to look out for. You will be automatically notified of a change in the list of weeds or pests. To manually update the list, go to:
Your phone will upload your observations automatically. You may turn off automatic upload if you have no reception or want to concerve battery life.

It will allow you to do two things:

(1) See a list of the top invasives

(2) Record an observation of an invasive.
Your observations are kept in the Queue for 1 minute to allow you to review and delete them before they are sent to our database.
From the list of top invasives:
Touch the thumbnail photo of the invasive for more information.
After clicking the \"Map a Weed!\" or \"Map a Pest!\" button:
To record an observation of an invasive:
(a) Select the quantity of weeds or pests that you see.
(b) Select if you want to include a photo or include notes about your observation.
(c) Then touch the name of the invasive to make your observation!
The \"My Results\" button will take you to your personal statistics:
You can also switch between statistics for you and all participants after clicking the MENU button on the phone.
If there are more than one user on your phone, you may switch users by resetting the login.

You may wish to turn off automatic upload if you are in an area with no reception or want to conserve battery life.\n\nOtherwise, your observations are automatically uploaded after 1 minute in the Queue.

When connected, your phone will automatically download a list of parks.

If GPS is enabled, your phone will automatically select the park closest to you and download its list of top invasives.

The selected park is displayed on the main page.
This will present a list of parks if you wish to manually select a park and turn off Auto-location.
You will be automatically notified of any change in the list of top invasives. This option is then required to manually update the list.
Select a park to download an invasives list. If GPS is enabled, the list includes only the ten closest parks to your current location. Check \"Show All Parks\" to show all the parks.
Select the quantity of weeds or pests that you see.
Select if you want to include a photo or add notes to your observation.
We recommend that you include at least one photo of each new invasive species you are recording.
Then touch the name of the invasive to make your observation!
Unable to download invasive list. Park does not exist.
Login timed out.\n\nMake sure you have network coverage.
The username and password cannot be empty.
It will allow you to do two things:
See the list of the top invasives.
Record an observation of an invasive.

What's Invasive! cannot access your location information.

You must enable the GPS satellites before proceeding.
If you choose not to, your park location will be set to the default park.
What\'s Invasive cannot access your location information.\n\nYour submissions will be uploaded normally, but you will have to set a location manually using the website.
A What\'s Invasive Update is available:\n
New Version of What\'s Invasive is Available
New Version of What\'s Invasive is Required
Please Uninstall the old version, go to the Android Market and search for "Invasive" for the new version.\n Update Details:\n

What\'s Invasive! for Android is designed to automatically upload user data to our What\'s Invasive servers. Would you like to set automatic upload on now? (Note: You can change this value later in Settings)
Invasive Mapped!\n\nYour observation will be in the Queue for 1 minute before upload.
Please wait while downloading invasives and thumbnails.
Please wait while the invasives list updates for the first time...

Your observations above are waiting to be sent to the server.

You may select any observation above to view or delete at this time.

Visit http://whatsinvasive.com to edit or delete your previously uploaded observations.
There is no associated location with this tag.
Invasives list download failed: HTTP timeout.
Invasives list download failed: No response from server.
GPS disabled, using Network location mode.
Network and GPS location modes disabled.
Please try retaking your photo at a lower resolution to aviod this error.
Failed to download results.\n\nMake sure you have network coverage before trying again.

While in Preview Mode, you can explore all the feautures of the application. However, you may only submit observations to the DEMO park.\n\nTo select the DEMO park please go to Settings->\"Show parks\" then select DEMO from the list.
Please wait while we upgade the data directory.
Enable or disable the upload service
Enable or disable the auto-location service
Update to the latest invasives lists
Enable the collection of debugging information
Send collection debugging information to the developers
